items.title: National ag teacher shortage threatens growth of FFA programs
items.description: As agriculture education programs continue to grow, schools and FFA chapters struggle to secure qualified agriculture teachers amid a national shortage. The post National ag teacher shortage threatens growth of FFA programs appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Key Points:

- There is a nationwide shortage of qualified agriculture teachers, which is the greatest challenge facing FFA and agriculture education programs.

- Over the past year, there was a net increase of almost 300 agriculture teaching positions nationwide, representing a 2% growth rate. However, 107 teaching positions were lost and 58 programs closed, primarily due to lack of available teachers, low enrollment, and insufficient funding.

- Reasons for the shortage include an aging teacher population, poor salaries compared to industry opportunities, heavy workloads, and the need for different instructional approaches in urban/suburban areas.

- The National FFA Foundation and National Association of Agricultural Educators (NAAE) have partnered with sponsors to provide $8,000 per state for recruiting future ag teachers.

- Universities like the University of Georgia and Abraham Baldwin Agricultural College are seeing steady or expanding enrollment in agricultural education programs.

- Initiatives like Georgia's "Hit the Ground Running" program provide support and mentorship for new agriculture teachers.

- The agriculture industry's reliance on qualified teachers is critical, especially in states like Georgia where agriculture is a top industry. Investing in and retaining ag teachers is essential for the future growth of the industry.

items.title: Bipartisan Bill Seeks to Advance Offshore U.S. Aquaculture
items.description: Small in comparison to coastal Norwegian salmon farms, with annual combined exports of 1.2 million tons, Blue Ocean Mariculture produces about 1,100 tons of fish annually in net pens submerged 30 to 130 feet under water. Roughly half the fish is sold to distributors and stores in Hawaii, while the rest goes to markets on […] The post Bipartisan Bill Seeks to Advance Offshore U.S. Aquaculture appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Blue Ocean Mariculture, a Hawaii-based offshore aquaculture company, produces around 1,100 tons of fish annually in net pens 30-130 feet underwater. They export about half their production to Hawaii markets, with the rest going to other US markets.

- In comparison, Norway's coastal salmon farms have annual exports of 1.2 million tons, dwarfing Blue Ocean's production.

- The bipartisan bill, called the Advancing the Quality and Understanding of American Aquaculture (AQUAA) Act, aims to establish a regulatory framework to promote and support offshore aquaculture in US federal waters.

- The bill is sponsored by Senators Roger Wicker (R-MS) and Brian Schatz (D-HI), along with Representatives Darren Soto (D-FL) and Ed Case (D-HI).

- Supporters say the bill would provide regulatory clarity and encourage investment in an industry they believe can help meet growing global seafood demand in a sustainable way.

- Critics argue the bill could have negative environmental impacts and say more research is needed on the industry's environmental effects.

The summary covers the key details from the article about the bill, aquaculture production figures, and the perspectives of supporters and critics.

items.title: North American Potato Production Falls On Lower Acreage
items.description: WASHINGTON, DC – Potato production across North America slipped in 2025, largely because growers planted [...]
items.summary: U.S. potato output fell to 413 million hundredweight, also down 2%, as growers reduced planted acreage by roughly 902,000 acres, the lowest level in nearly 10 years. While yields improved modestly, they could not offset the acreage pullback. Canada's production edged 1% lower despite expanded planted acreage, as yields slipped year-over-year. Mexico increased potato output in 2024 due to higher yields and a larger harvested area, partially offsetting declines in the north. Across North America, total potato acreage in 2025 marked the smallest footprint since the mid-2010s, reflecting cautious planting decisions by growers amid rising costs and uncertain returns.

items.title: USDA Debuts Plan to End ‚ÄòAgricultural Lawfare‚Äô
items.description: February 12, 2026 ‚Äì Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins on Wednesday announced a plan to address an issue the Trump administration is calling ‚Äúagricultural lawfare.‚Äù Rollins made the announcement at an event with officials from other federal agencies and a group of farmers and ranchers, coinciding with the release of the Farmer and Rancher Freedom Framework. […] The post USDA Debuts Plan to End ‚ÄòAgricultural Lawfare‚Äô appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
The USDA has unveiled a plan to address "agricultural lawfare" - the use of lawsuits to undermine agricultural practices. On February 12, 2026, Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins announced the Farmer and Rancher Freedom Framework at an event with federal agencies and farmers/ranchers.

The key elements of the plan include:
- Establishing a new USDA Office of Legal Defense to provide farmers/ranchers with legal support against lawsuits
- Implementing a "Right to Farm" law to protect farmers/ranchers from nuisance lawsuits
- Creating a USDA Legal Defense Fund to cover legal costs for farmers/ranchers
- Expanding the scope of the Farmer and Rancher Disaster Program to include legal expenses

The goal is to help farmers/ranchers defend themselves against lawsuits that aim to restrict agricultural practices. This is expected to provide $150 million per year in legal support to the farming community. Supporters say it will protect the livelihoods of farmers and ranchers, while critics argue it could enable harmful agricultural practices.

items.title: Texas A&M hires new wildlife management and conservation policy expert
items.description: Cain to build natural resource stewardship research program to guide policy across Texas and beyond The post Texas A&M hires new wildlife management and conservation policy expert appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Texas A&M University has hired James Cain, Ph.D., as the new associate professor and Boone and Crockett Chair in Wildlife Conservation and Policy in the Department of Rangeland, Wildlife and Fisheries Management. 

Cain brings over 20 years of academic experience in large mammal ecology, applied wildlife management, and collaborative conservation. He will strengthen the department's holistic approach to natural resource stewardship, using rigorous scientific data and diverse stakeholder engagement to inform policy and outreach.

Cain's research program will focus on contemporary conservation and policy topics, including land use, drought, habitat loss, wildlife-habitat relationships, predator-prey interactions, and wildlife disease. These issues are relevant to Texas and the southwestern U.S., where Cain has conducted previous research on species such as black bear, bighorn sheep, elk, and pronghorn.

Cain will also coordinate and expand the department's Dr. James "Red" Duke '50 Boone and Crockett Wildlife Conservation and Policy Program, a five-year joint-degree program with the Texas A&M Bush School of Government and Public Service. The program integrates wildlife science and management with policies for natural resource stewardship on public and private lands.

Cain's goal is to educate and mentor students to become highly proficient professionals with a solid understanding of both wildlife biology and the policy realm, while also providing sound, actionable science to wildlife and land managers to support effective natural resource decisions.

items.title: Texas A&M hospitality leader earns international research award
items.description: Michael D. Olsen Research Achievement Award recognizes global hospitality and tourism scholarship impact The post Texas A&M hospitality leader earns international research award appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Key Points:

- Brian King, Ph.D., professor and department head of the Arch H. Aplin III '80 Department of Hospitality, Hotel Management and Tourism at Texas A&M College of Agriculture and Life Sciences, has received the 2026 Michael D. Olsen Research Achievement Award.

- The award is presented by the Hospitality and Tourism Educators Association and honors scholars whose research and academic leadership have made sustained contributions to hospitality and tourism education.

- King's scholarly work spans industry engagement, research, and teaching. He has international consulting experience with organizations like the UN and EU, and is the founding editor-in-chief of the journal Tourism, Culture & Communication.

- King joined Texas A&M in 2022 after an academic career in Europe, Australia, the Pacific, and Asia, including roles as associate dean at Hong Kong Polytechnic University and senior leadership positions at Victoria University in Australia.

- As head of the Aplin Department, King leads teaching, research, and outreach initiatives emphasizing graduate education, mentorship, and global engagement in hospitality and tourism.

items.title: Reclaiming harsh habitats with black soldier fly larvae
items.description: Collaborative research supported by the WoodNext Foundation aims to autonomize rehabilitation of extreme environments The post Reclaiming harsh habitats with black soldier fly larvae appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

- Researchers from Texas A&M University, supported by the WoodNext Foundation, aim to rehabilitate extreme environments using black soldier fly larvae, robotics, AI, and sensor technology.

- The project is led by Jeffery Tomberlin, a Texas A&M AgriLife Research Fellow, who will utilize the larvae's ability to recycle organic waste and remove toxic substances.

- Guillermo Aguilar will develop advanced sensors to monitor soil composition, contaminant levels, and nutrient dynamics.

- Minghui Zheng will build robotic systems to automate remediation tasks, reducing human exposure to hazardous environments.

- Xiao Liang will lead the AI component to optimize efficiency, scalability, and reduce manual oversight in soil remediation.

- The research is supported by the WoodNext Foundation, a donor-advised fund program of tech innovator and Roku CEO/founder Anthony Wood '87 and his wife, Susan '89.

- The goal is to turn contaminated land into productive soil suitable for human habitation, with potential applications for extraterrestrial environments like Mars or the moon.

items.title: USDA Opens ‚ÄòSterile Fly‚Äô Facility to Prevent Cattle Disease
items.description: February 11, 2026 – Secretary of Agriculture Brooke Rollins joined Governor Greg Abbott in Texas Monday to announce the opening of a new U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) facility that will be able to disperse sterile flies in an effort to prevent the spread of New World screwworm flies, which can kill cattle and other […] The post USDA Opens ‚ÄòSterile Fly‚Äô Facility to Prevent Cattle Disease appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary: The USDA has opened a new facility in Texas that will produce and disperse sterile flies to prevent the spread of New World screwworm flies. These flies can kill cattle and other livestock. The facility was opened on February 11, 2026 by USDA Secretary Brooke Rollins and Texas Governor Greg Abbott. The facility will be able to disperse the sterile flies as part of an effort to control the screwworm fly population and protect the cattle industry. This is an important development for cattle farmers in Texas and surrounding areas, as screwworm flies can cause significant economic losses if left unchecked.

items.title: Remember to register for the Nitrogen Conference - this Tuesday Feb. 17th, 2026 in St. Cloud
items.summary:
Key details:

- The 12th annual Nitrogen Conference is taking place on Tuesday, February 17, 2026 in St. Cloud, Minnesota. 

- The conference will explore how nitrogen management impacts crop production, the environment, and soil productivity. It will feature research updates and a farmer panel on nitrogen management.

- Registration cost is $20. Attendees can participate in-person or virtually (with lunch included for in-person).

- Presentations will cover topics like the MRTN calculator, cover crop impacts, precision irrigation, the PSNT, biologicals for nutrient management, soil organic matter, and nitrate issues in water.

- Certified Crop Advisers can earn continuing education credits by attending.

- To stay up to date, farmers can subscribe to the Nutrient Management Podcast, the Minnesota Crop News email, the UMN Extension Nutrient Management YouTube channel, and Facebook page.

items.title: Through Food and Culture, the East Bay Ohlone Are Repairing Centuries of Harm
items.description: Photographs by Aya Brackett I‚Äôm Louis Trevino. Most importantly, I‚Äôm Vincent‚Äôs partner in life and in love, for which I am every day so very grateful. And I too am Ohlone from here in the East Bay, and I have dedicated myself to Vincent and to his beautiful and dynamic vision for our people and […] The post Through Food and Culture, the East Bay Ohlone Are Repairing Centuries of Harm appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Vincent Medina and Louis Trevino, both members of the Ohlone community, are working to revive Ohlone food traditions and share their culture. 
- They have established a farm and food business called Cafe Ohlone to showcase traditional Ohlone cuisine and ingredients.
- The Ohlone people were nearly wiped out by Spanish colonization and later policies, losing much of their cultural knowledge and practices.
- Medina and Trevino are working to reconnect their community with traditional foods, plants, and stories, as a way to heal from this history of oppression.
- Their work includes hosting educational events, teaching traditional cooking methods, and growing indigenous crops like acorns and wild greens.
- The goal is to not only preserve Ohlone culture, but also empower the community and share their vibrant heritage with the broader public.

items.title: MN CropCast: From research to resilience - Advancing soil health with Dr. Anna Cates
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

- Dr. Anna Cates, the University of Minnesota Extension Soil Health Specialist, was interviewed on the Minnesota CropCast podcast (Episode #56) on February 10, 2026.

- Dr. Cates leads the MN Office for Soil Health (MOSH), which works with farmers and conservation professionals to improve soil health across Minnesota.

- MOSH partners with the Minnesota Board of Water and Soil Resources (BWSR) to provide funding, policy implementation, and technical guidance to local Soil and Water Conservation Districts (SWCDs).

- The podcast discusses farmer adoption of conservation practices and cover crops, as well as an upcoming intensive educational opportunity called the Cover Crop Academy.

- Dr. Cates has a PhD in Agronomy and MS in Soil Science and Agroecology from the University of Wisconsin-Madison, and her work aims to turn soil health research into on-the-ground conservation.

- The Minnesota CropCast podcast is hosted by David Nicolai, a crops Extension educator, and Seth Naeve, the Extension soybean agronomist, and covers progress and challenges of Minnesota's agronomic crops.

items.title: Minnesota Irrigator Program returns March 10th and 11th, 2026 in Perham, MN
items.summary:
The Minnesota Irrigator Program (MIP) is returning on March 10th and 11th, 2026 in Perham, MN. The 2-day program, which costs $60, will cover topics such as irrigation scheduling, variable rate technology, autonomous pivots, flowmeters and calibration, and nitrogen management. Breakfast and lunch will be provided each day. 

Completing the MIP is one of the requirements to attain the Irrigation Endorsement of the Minnesota Agricultural Water Quality Certification Program (MAWQCP). Certified farms that attend the program and adopt a new irrigation practice or scheduling method on-farm will receive the endorsement.

The program aims to help irrigators and irrigation professionals match irrigation to crop water use, improve water-use efficiency, and reduce water costs, given Minnesota's sandy soils and varying rainfall. Efficient agricultural irrigation has become a key topic in the state due to these conditions.

The event will be held at the Cactus Event Center: 43521 Fort Thunder Rd, Perham, MN 56573. Registration is available at z.umn.edu/MIP2026.

items.title: 7 Vegetables to Start From Seed in February
items.description: It takes a lot to get the farm ready for the growing season. It all begins with the task of gathering together and starting vegetable seeds. February is an ideal time to get many of your spring crops going. Consider these 7 vegetables as you prepare your rows. The post 7 Vegetables to Start From Seed in February appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
Key Points from the Article:

1. February is a good time to start growing vegetable seeds, especially for crops that take a long time to mature.
2. Slow-growing herbs like basil, oregano, and rosemary should be planted in February to ensure mature transplants.
3. Tomatoes should be started indoors in February, especially for growers with short seasons. Determinate varieties are best for short seasons, while indeterminate varieties are good for year-round harvests.
4. Peppers are notoriously slow to germinate and benefit from an early start in February. They can take up to a month to sprout and require a heat mat and ample light.
5. Brassicas like broccoli, cabbage, and cauliflower thrive in the cool weather of mid to late winter and early spring.
6. Lettuce is an easy-to-grow green that can be started directly outdoors in February, as it can handle a little late frost.
7. Carrots and parsnips should be direct-sown outdoors under row cover in February, as their deep taproots are sensitive to root disturbance.
8. Onions and leeks should be planted in February to ensure healthy transplants when the ground warms.
9. Farmers in cold climates can use protected environments like greenhouses, cold frames, and low/high tunnels to start seeds in February.

items.title: Why Attention Matters More Than Response for Advertisers
items.description: For many years, click-through rate was the primary metric used to judge digital performance in agriculture. Today, it no longer tells the full story. Farmers are searching differently, using AI-assisted tools, voice search and quick-scan platforms that often answer their questions without the need to click at all. With this shift, the true indicator of […] The post Why Attention Matters More Than Response for Advertisers appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
Attention time, or the amount of time a user spends meaningfully engaged with content, is now a more valuable indicator of effectiveness. 

Recent redesigns of AgWeb.com were intentionally focused on increasing user attention and engagement:
- 54% increase in readers reaching 75% of an article 
- 21% increase in readers reaching 90% of an article
- 33% increase in daily article pageviews per mobile user

The article notes that in general, only 16% of online readers read every word, while 79% scan pages rather than reading fully. By simplifying layouts and guiding deeper engagement, AgWeb has created an environment where ads are not just viewable, but genuinely noticed.

Attention time directly influences brand recall, message retention, and advertising effectiveness. High-attention environments deliver stronger results because the brand is present during engaged moments, not fleeting ones. 

The improvements to AgWeb translate to more value for advertisers, with more time spent with content, more articles consumed per session, higher quality impressions, and better alignment to how farmers search today. As attention becomes the priority metric, the article states this offers one of the most effective digital environments for agricultural marketers.

items.title: The February Greenhouse: What to Grow Now
items.description: When winter is halfway over, growing out of the elements is the only option for many farmers. Here, we share how to use a greenhouse to grow what the climate doesn‚Äôt allow and keep the revenue flowing. The post The February Greenhouse: What to Grow Now appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
- February is a good time to start late spring transplants and quick-maturing crops for early spring markets.
- Key greenhouse elements are the ability to trap and circulate heat, and vent air as needed.
- Different types of greenhouses include modular plastic (can raise temps 30¬∞F), low tunnels (2-15¬∞F warmer), cold frames (5-15¬∞F warmer), and designer greenhouses with climate controls.
- Good greenhouse crops for February include tomatoes and peppers (need consistent warmth of at least 50¬∞F), brassicas like kale and cabbage (shelter from pests/cold), lettuces, potatoes, onions, and flowers like lisianthus.
- Greenhouse growing allows earlier starts for many crops, avoiding issues like potato beetles and extending the growing season.
- Key recommendations are to match crops to greenhouse type, provide consistent warmth and moisture, and use features like lights and timers to optimize growing conditions.

items.title: Farm Journal and Hass Avocado Board Launch The Avocado Conference
items.description: Kansas City, MO., (January 28, 2026) ‚Äì  The Packer, the produce industry‚Äôs premier publication from Farm Journal, announced the launch of The Avocado Conference, a first-of-its-kind international event gathering every segment of the U.S. avocado supply chain. The inaugural event is set for Nov. 18-20, 2026, at the Hilton San Diego Bayfront. The conference directly […] The post Farm Journal and Hass Avocado Board Launch The Avocado Conference appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

- The Packer, a publication from Farm Journal, is launching "The Avocado Conference" - a first-of-its-kind international event for the U.S. avocado supply chain.

- The inaugural event is set for November 18-20, 2026 in San Diego, California.

- The conference is being launched in direct support of the Hass Avocado Board's (HAB) mission to strengthen the global avocado industry and make Hass avocados America's preferred healthy food.

- The event aims to be a forum for collaboration, data-driven insights, supply-and-demand analysis, and strategic industry alignment among all avocado supply chain stakeholders.

- Sessions will cover global avocado production and trade, retail/foodservice market insights, consumer/shopper trends, avocado marketing, and the Hass Avocado Board's efforts to expand avocado demand.

- Key stakeholders attending will include growers, packers, importers/exporters, retail/foodservice buyers, input suppliers, and data/insights providers.

- The Hass Avocado Board is collaborating on content development and will play a critical role in uniting the avocado industry for this event.

items.title: New Training Materials Available for Iowa Pesticide Applicators
items.description: The Iowa State University Pesticide Safety Education Program has revised several applicator manuals and exams to reflect the updated pesticide applicator certification and training rules implemented by the Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship on Jan. 1.
items.summary: The Iowa State University Pesticide Safety Education Program has revised several applicator manuals and exams to reflect the updated pesticide applicator certification and training rules implemented by the Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship on January 1, 2026. The updated training manuals, including the Iowa Core Manual (CS445) and the Private Pesticide Applicator Manual (CS1), are now available for purchase through the ISU Extension Store. New exams based on the revised core manual are available at all Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship test sites. The updated Private Pesticide Applicator Manual includes a two-page informational insert, and all private exams now include content from this insert. For more information, farmers can contact Betsy Danielson, the Pesticide Safety Education Extension Specialist at Iowa State University, at betsydan@iastate.edu.

items.title: Stop Chasing Leads. Start Designing the Right Offer.
items.description: Lead generation starts with delivering real value in exchange for a farmer‚Äôs time and attention. The CTA and offer you choose shape not only how many leads you capture, but how qualified, motivated and purchase-ready those prospects become. When you shift your mindset from what you want to collect to what farmers genuinely need in […] The post Stop Chasing Leads. Start Designing the Right Offer. appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
The key points are:

- Lead generation should focus on delivering real value to farmers in exchange for their time and attention, rather than just collecting leads.
- The call-to-action (CTA) and offer chosen shape not only the number of leads captured, but also their quality, motivation, and purchase-readiness.
- Shifting the mindset from what the business wants to collect to what farmers genuinely need is crucial for effective lead generation.
- Designing the right offer requires understanding the farmers' specific problems, challenges, and needs.
- Effective offers provide practical solutions, insights, or tools that truly benefit the farmers.
- This approach leads to higher-quality leads that are more likely to convert into customers.

items.title: Brand and Content Discoverability Is the New Battleground in Ag Marketing
items.description: The world is searching for information a bit differently these days. Gone are the days of winning the click (traditional SEO). The game now is centered on winning brand authority and trust (modern AEO, answer engine optimization). In a world now crowded with ‚ÄúAI slop,‚Äù brands will only cut through by growing brand authority and […] The post Brand and Content Discoverability Is the New Battleground in Ag Marketing appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
Key points:
- The traditional focus on winning the click (SEO) has shifted to winning brand authority and trust (AEO or answer engine optimization).
- Farmers are now relying more on AI-powered search engines like ChatGPT and Google's AI Overviews, which provide instant, direct answers to their questions.
- If brands are not present in these new discovery channels, they risk being invisible to their audience.
- Farm Journal is observing and adapting to this shift in discoverability, which should prompt all ag marketers to reevaluate their strategies for 2026.
- An answer-driven content strategy and amplifying trusted voices will be more important than ever.
- Discoverability is now about winning the citation, the brand mention, and the trusted source reference that builds brand authority, even in zero-click moments.

items.title: Forest Farming: Why it Might Make Sense for Your Land
items.description: Also called agroforestry, forest farming is a great way to work within your environmental parameters and utilize the tree canopy to produce more for your farm. Especially for those who live in forested areas, this practice enhances farm output without compromising the ecosystem. The post Forest Farming: Why it Might Make Sense for Your Land appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
Also called "multi-story cropping" or "agroforestry", it allows farmers to seamlessly integrate their farm into the surrounding landscape and diversify their product offerings.

Originating in tropical Brazil, forest farming is well-suited for land on the margins of forests. It involves thinning a forest to allow for crops to grow in the understory, including native ornamentals, fungi, fruit, timber, and forest food crops. Other agroforestry methods mentioned include silvopasture (combining forestry and ranching) and alley cropping (planting specialty crops between tree rows).

Key benefits of forest farming include:
- Improved water and soil quality, with trees holding more water and carbon
- Habitat for beneficial insects, birds, mammals, fungi, and microbes
- Ability to grow specialized crops like mushrooms, ramps, syrups, and edible roots

Farmers are advised to inventory their existing natural resources, consult extension services to develop a management plan, and explore diverse marketing channels for forest products. Regulations around wild-harvested plants also need to be considered.

Overall, the article states that forest farming can be an inexpensive and ecologically-beneficial way for farmers with forested land to diversify their operations, even on a small scale.

items.title: Getting Started with Spray Drones in Iowa: A Practical Guide
items.description: Spray drones are increasingly being evaluated by Iowa farmers as an additional tool for crop input application. When used appropriately, these systems can provide flexibility for timely applications, reduce fi
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

- Spray drones are being increasingly evaluated by Iowa farmers as an additional tool for crop input application.
- Key benefits include timely applications, reduced field traffic, and improved access to difficult areas.
- Adoption requires careful consideration of regulations, training, insurance, and management practices.

Regulations:
- FAA Part 107 Remote Pilot Certificate is required to operate drones commercially.
- FAA Part 137 Certification is required for aerial application of pesticides.
- Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship (IDALS) licensing is required for all aerial applicators.
- Only products labeled for aerial application may be legally applied using a drone.

Insurance:
- Most standard farm liability policies do not cover aerial pesticide application or aircraft-related risks.
- Farmers need chemical liability, general liability, and hull/physical damage coverage.

Equipment Selection:
- Consider spray tank capacity, battery life, nozzle options, GPS guidance, and local dealer support.

Training and Safe Operation:
- Proper training is essential for effective and safe spray drone use.
- Calibration, weather monitoring, and routine maintenance are critical.
- Verifying swath width is crucial for consistent spray performance.

Gradual Adoption:
- Start on a limited scale with small acreage or trial fields.
- Develop efficient procedures for mixing, refilling, and battery exchange.
- Cautiously evaluate dry product uses like cover crop seeding or spot fertilizer placement.

Resources:
- Iowa State University Extension, Digital Agriculture Innovation Lab, licensed equipment dealers, and IDALS.

Key Dates:
- February 24-25, 2026: 2-day FAA Part 107 training workshop in Ames, IA.

items.title: The 9 Best Flowers and Vegetables to Winter Sow
items.description: For farms in colder areas, starting seeds in time for the spring market requires a significant amount of time and indoor space. Winter sowing is a method that can be done outdoors and gives seedlings a stronger constitution as they mature. Here, we share plants that thrive when winter sown. The post The 9 Best Flowers and Vegetables to Winter Sow appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
Winter sowing involves starting seeds in containers like milk jugs or plastic bags and placing them outdoors, where the cold, moist conditions help the seeds break dormancy. This results in hardier transplants and plants that mature sooner.

The article then provides details on the best flowers and vegetables to winter sow:

Vegetables:
- Cabbages - Excellent cold-tolerant options include standard cabbages, Napa cabbages, and 'Carex' cabbages with shorter maturation.
- Spinach - Varieties like 'Avon' and 'Space' are good options, as they are resistant to mildew and bolting.
- Onions - Long-day, short-day, and intermediate-day onion varieties can all be winter sown. Bunching onions and shallots also work well.
- Leafy greens - Kale, collards, chard, watercress, microgreens, bok choy, arugula, and beet/turnip greens are all excellent for winter sowing.

Flowers:
- Pansies - Hardy pansies can be planted now for spring blooms.
- Echinacea - Needs cold stratification, which is provided by the winter sowing method.
- Snapdragons - There are four groups, each suited for different light and temperature conditions.
- Larkspur - Also known as delphinium, these produce beautiful true-blue flowers and attract pollinators.
- Scabiosa - Also called pincushion flowers, these attract beneficial insects to the farm.

The article emphasizes that winter sowing provides the benefits of direct sowing with less risk, and highlights the importance of choosing the right plants for this method.

items.title: 5 Agri-Environmental Strategies that Prevent Species Loss
items.description: On today‚Äôs farms, ecologically-friendly practices are on the rise. Using agri-environmental strategies, farmers prevent environmental degradation, preserving natural spaces and the species that live in them. The post 5 Agri-Environmental Strategies that Prevent Species Loss appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
Prairie Strips - Planting 10-25% of farmland with prairie strips can attract beneficial predators, improve soil nutrients, and boost crop yields. The diverse flowers and plants support pollinators, pest-controlling insects, and soil microorganisms.

2. Low Tilling - Reducing tillage and using cover crops can improve soil structure and biodiversity, supporting a healthier ecosystem above and below ground. This reduces the need for heavy equipment that can damage soil life.

3. Regenerative Grazing - Using rotational grazing models, planting native species, and managing invasives can improve rangeland health and biodiversity, especially when combined with practices like silvopasture (integrating trees).

4. Integrated Pest Management (IPM) - Attracting beneficial insects through diverse plantings and cultural pest control methods, rather than relying on pesticides, can protect biodiversity while still managing pests.

5. Conservation Easements - Partnering with land trusts to place farmland under conservation easements can protect natural habitats and resources, while also providing landowners with tax benefits.

The article states these strategies are worthwhile, as maintaining habitat for pollinators and pest-controlling species reduces the need for costly agricultural inputs. Experts emphasize the importance of viewing the farm as part of a larger natural system, rather than isolating it. Implementing these practices can make farms more productive and sustainable in the long run.

items.title: 2026 Crop Advantage Series Meetings to Be Held at 12 Locations in January
items.description: AMES, Iowa ‚Äì The 2026 Crop Advantage Series will take place at 12 locations across the state Jan. 6‚Äì29. Each meeting will feature tailored topics selected based on local growing conditions and challenges, presented by Iowa State University Extension and Outreach specialists.
items.summary:
The 2026 Crop Advantage Series will be held at 12 locations across Iowa from January 6-29. These meetings, organized by Iowa State University Extension and Outreach, will provide farmers and crop production professionals with the latest research-based information to help them make informed decisions for the upcoming growing season.

- Profitable nutrient management
- Southern rust

Early-bird registration is $75 until the week before each meeting, after which it will be $100. Private pesticide applicator recertification will also be available at each location for a separate fee of $30.

The goal of the Crop Advantage Series is to help producers manage potential issues by sharing the most up-to-date scientific knowledge from Iowa State University researchers. The content for each location is tailored based on local growing conditions and challenges.

For more information, farmers can contact crops@iastate.edu or their regional ISU Extension and Outreach field agronomist. Registration and additional details are available on the Crop Advantage Series registration site.

items.title: Farm Journal Announces 2026 Top Producer Award Finalists
items.description: Outstanding producers from California, Kansas, Ohio, Oregon and Wisconsin will be recognized for excellence, leadership and innovation. Kansas City, Mo., (Dec. 15, 2025) ‚Äì Farm Journal has announced three finalists for the prestigious 2026 Top Producer of the Year Award, honoring some of the most progressive and successful farm operations in the country. The winner and finalists will be […] The post Farm Journal Announces 2026 Top Producer Award Finalists appeared first
items.summary:
The Farm Journal has announced the finalists for the prestigious 2026 Top Producer of the Year Award, recognizing outstanding producers from California, Kansas, Ohio, Oregon, and Wisconsin for their excellence, leadership, and innovation.

The three finalists are:

1. Alsum Farms, Friesland, Wis. - A multigenerational family operation producing potatoes, pumpkins, hay, and other crops on over 3,600 acres. The business is fully vertically integrated.

2. Dalton Farms, Wakeman, Ohio - A seventh-generation family farm led by Rebecca and Edward Dalton, with 2,000 acres of corn and soybeans, a 400-head cattle herd, and a growing on-farm market.

3. Splitter Farms, Sterling, Kan. - Led by Matt and Janna Splitter, this Kansas row-crop operation spans 1,400 owned acres with nearly 18,500 acres farmed annually through cash rent and custom work.

The winner and finalists will be recognized at the 2026 Top Producer Summit in Nashville, Tenn., on February 9-11. The event will also present the Next Generation Award and Women in Agriculture Award.

The 2026 Next Generation Award winner is Tim Nuss, El Dorado Hills/Lodi, Calif., who farms various crops and is also involved in ag tech and influencing. The 2026 Women in Agriculture Award winner is Helle Ruddenklau, Amity, Ore., who grows grass seed, wheat, vegetables, peas, and hazelnuts, and is active in ag advocacy and economic development.

The Top Producer Awards are sponsored by BASF, Fendt, and Pro Farmer.

items.title: Purdue field day to feature research on sorghum‚Äôs value as a forage crop
items.description: Purdue University Extension will host a Forage Sorghum Field Day on Sept. 10 at the Feldun-Purdue Ag Center (FPAC) in Bedford, Indiana.
items.summary:
Purdue University Extension will host a Forage Sorghum Field Day on September 10 at the Feldun-Purdue Ag Center in Bedford, Indiana. Interested participants should register by September 5.

The event will feature research on sorghum's value as a forage crop compared to corn. Sorghum is more drought-tolerant, has lower nitrogen requirements, and is not susceptible to the tar spot pathogen. Attendees will learn about sorghum production and utilization for silage, grazing, and as a standing winter feed source.

Speakers will include Purdue experts such as Keith Johnson, Mitch Tuinstra, Brad Shelton, Jason Tower, Nick Minton, and Jeff Jackson. They will discuss topics like plant breeding techniques to improve sorghum yield and quality.

The event will include venue tours from 3-5 pm and 6-8 pm, as well as a dinner and bull test station tour from 5-6 pm.

items.title: Farmer sentiment improves despite financial performance concerns
items.description: Three broad-based measures of farmer sentiment improved in July as the Purdue University/CME Group Ag Economy Barometer index rose 8 points to 113, the Index of Current Conditions increased by 10 points to 100, and the Index of Future Expectations at 119 was 7 points higher than a month earlier. Despite declines in corn and soybean prices from mid-June to mid-July ‚Äî Eastern Corn Belt cash prices fell 11% and 5%, respectively ‚Äî farmer sentiment improved in July. Responses to the individual questi
items.summary:
Farmer sentiment improved in July 2024 despite concerns over financial performance:

- The Purdue University/CME Group Ag Economy Barometer index rose 8 points to 113 in July.
- The Index of Current Conditions increased by 10 points to 100, and the Index of Future Expectations rose 7 points to 119.
- This positive shift was attributed to fewer respondents reporting worsened conditions compared to a year ago and a decrease in those expecting negative future outcomes.
- High input costs remained the biggest concern for 34% of farmers, while 29% cited the risk of lower crop and livestock prices, up from 25% in June.
- The Farm Financial Performance Index dropped 4 points in July to 81, 6 points lower than July 2023, reflecting farmers' worries about weakening commodity prices and high input costs.
- The Farm Capital Investment Index rose 6 points in July to 38, though it remains 7 points lower than July 2023, as fewer producers believe it's a bad time to make large investments.
- The Short-Term Farmland Value Expectations Index rose to 118 from 115 in June, while the Long-Term Farmland Value Expectations Index dropped 6 points to 146.
- Nearly three-fourths (72%) of crop farmer respondents expect cash rental rates to remain the same in 2025 compared to 2024.

items.title: Purdue researchers adopt interdisciplinary approach to assessing emerging tar spot disease in corn
items.description: For more than a century, tar spot fungal disease in corn kept its distance from the U.S., biding its time
items.summary:
Purdue researchers are taking an interdisciplinary approach to assess the emerging tar spot disease in corn:

- Tar spot, a fungal disease, was first detected in the U.S. in 2015 and has since spread to 16 states and Ontario, Canada by 2022. It has also affected crops in 15 other countries.

- The research team, led by C.D. Cruz, associate professor of botany and plant pathology at Purdue, is using a mix of statistical, data science, epidemiology, microbiology, artificial intelligence, and computer vision methods to understand the dynamics of tar spot.

- The research is funded by two USDA grants totaling nearly $1.1 million. Collaborators include researchers from Colombia, Mexico, Ecuador, South Korea, and the U.S.

- Researchers have developed a digital method (SCDA) to quantify tar spot in corn, which they have tested against human raters with promising results. They are now refining the training methods to improve the model's accuracy.

- The team is also exploring the use of drone imagery, weather data, and AI-based data fusion to capture details about the tar spot pathosystem, going beyond traditional weather-based models.

- The interdisciplinary approach involves challenges, but it can lead to better problem-solving by leveraging the expertise of researchers from different fields.

- The overall goal is to quantify and model tar spot severity by integrating various data sources, with the aim of providing rapid and accurate information to stakeholders.

items.title: ISA will host sheep-themed educational opportunities and competitions at Indiana State Fair
items.description: In addition to 4-H and open sheep shows, the Indiana Sheep Association (ISA) is sponsoring sheep-themed competitions, vendors and educational opportunities at this year‚Äôs Indiana State Fair, with additional support from the Indiana Sheep and Wool Market Development Program (IN SW).
items.summary:
Key Summary:

The Indiana Sheep Association (ISA), with support from the Indiana Sheep and Wool Market Development Program (IN S&W), is sponsoring various sheep-themed events and competitions at the 2024 Indiana State Fair, including:

- The Wool and Ewe Room and Ewe2 boutique selling wool products and Indiana lamb throughout the fair
- Open wool judging and wool sale on August 2 at 10 a.m.
- Make It With Wool (MIWW) competition and fashion show on August 4 at 2 p.m.
- Indiana State Fair Shearing Contest on August 4 at 5 p.m.
- Taste from Indiana Farms lamb sampling event from August 8-11 from 11 a.m.-6 p.m.
- Sheep to Shawl competition on August 18 at 10 a.m.

Additionally, sheep will be featured in the Blue Ribbon Pavilion for open and 4-H shows from August 4-20. The events aim to showcase the art, nature, and value of the sheep industry to fair attendees.

The ISA was originally founded in 1876 as the Indiana Wool Growers Association. The IN S&W program collects 0.5% of the net market price of each sheep sold in Indiana to fund educational, promotional, and research efforts.

items.title: Purdue Extension to present engaging art and nature demonstrations at Indiana State Fair
items.description: The Indiana State Fair kicks off Aug. 2 and highlights the theme ‚ÄúThe Art Nature of Fun‚Äù in collaboration with Newfields. Fairgoers will have the opportunity to speak with Purdue University representatives about agricultural and nature-related topics, which are available year-round through Purdue Extension.
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

- Purdue Extension will present interactive demonstrations and exhibits at the 2024 Indiana State Fair, which runs from August 2-18.
- The fair's theme is "The Art & Nature of Fun" in collaboration with Newfields.
- Purdue Extension exhibits will be located throughout the fairgrounds, covering topics like entomology, human health, forestry, and animal sciences.
- Specific activities include a Block Party, Book Party, Captain Cash financial management exhibit, and displays on pollinators and master gardening.
- The Food Science Department will host "What's Growing on My Spinach?" to explore food microbiology and safety, and offer samples of cricket-infused rice cereal treats.
- Seed art displays related to the fair's theme will be featured in livestock barns and the Purdue Extension Building.
- The Pioneer Village in the fairgrounds will transport visitors to the 1800s and feature antique tractors, a farm toy show, and more.

items.title: Potassium Cycle now available!
items.description: Check out the new NPM publication! This two-page publication gives a visual overview of the potassium cycle as it relates to general Wisconsin cropping systems, and on the second page, outlines some key potassium concepts …
items.summary: The University of Wisconsin-Madison has released a new publication called "Potassium Cycle" that provides a visual overview of the potassium cycle in Wisconsin cropping systems. The two-page publication covers key potassium concepts and recommendations for specific situations. The publication is available for download only and was released on June 12, 2024 through the Wisconsin Crop Manager newsletter.

items.title: Wisconsin Winter Wheat Update
items.description: Damon Smith, Extension Field Crops Pathologist, Shawn Conley, Extension Soybean and Small Grains Agronomist, University of Wisconsin-Madison Winter wheat in Wisconsin continues to move through growth stages at record pace. We are about 10-14 days …
items.summary:
Stripe rust disease is likely to be seen this season, though it has not been detected yet. Farmers are advised to scout fields and report any confirmed cases to the Plant Disease Diagnostic Clinic.  

Fusarium head blight (FHB) is also a concern, as the moderate temperatures and adequate precipitation this season create conditions favorable for the disease. FHB can limit yields and produce the mycotoxin deoxynivalenol (DON or vomitoxin), which can lead to grain being discounted or rejected at elevators if levels exceed 2 parts per million (ppm). Farmers will need to manage this disease.

The article was written on May 20, 2024 by Damon Smith, Extension Field Crops Pathologist, and Shawn Conley, Extension Soybean and Small Grains Agronomist, at the University of Wisconsin-Madison.

items.title: Questions to consider prior to replanting a soybean field
items.description: Shawn P. Conley, Soybean and Small Grains Specialist, UW-Madison Early in the growing season, abiotic (freezing temperatures, hail, flooding, etc.) and biotic (slugs, deer, disease, insects, etc.) factors often reduce soybean plant stands. A soybean …
items.summary:
Even minor stand loss warrants assessing the amount and pattern of plant loss. Stands below 50,000-60,000 plants per acre in southern regions or 75,000 plants per acre in northern regions, or areas larger than 6-10 square feet without any plants, should be considered for replanting.

Factors to evaluate include the existing plant stand, distribution, and ability to recover; calendar date and impact on relative maturity; weed management; seed and variety availability; cost to replant and insurance availability; and the tradeoff between a suboptimal stand vs. yield penalty from delayed replanting.

The article references a fact sheet with more detailed guidance, and a separate related article on "Soybean Replant Decisions Made Easy(ish)!".

items.title: Spraying 2,4-D on Soybean in 2024?
items.description: Daniel H. Smith, Outreach Program Manager, UW-Madison Division of Extension, Rodrigo Werle, Weed Scientist and Extension Specialist, UW-Madison Are you planning to spray 2,4-D for postemergence broadleaf weed control in Enlist E3 soybean? The 2,4-D …
items.summary:
The only labeled formulation for this application is the 2,4-D choline formulation present in Enlist One and Enlist Duo herbicides. The ester and amine formulations of 2,4-D cannot be used post-emergence in Enlist E3 soybeans. 

When using a 2,4-D ester or amine formulation product for burndown applications, there is a soybean plant back interval of at least 7 days when applying 0.5 lbs ae/acre. If planting Enlist E3 soybeans, Enlist One or Enlist Duo can be applied without this plant back restriction.

The article is a reminder that the product label must be followed, as there have been reports of producers, agronomists, and crop advisors considering using unapproved 2,4-D formulations for post-emergence applications in Enlist E3 soybeans.

The article was written by Daniel H. Smith, Outreach Program Manager at UW-Madison Division of Extension, and Rodrigo Werle, Weed Scientist and Extension Specialist at UW-Madison. It was posted on May 11, 2024.

items.title: Wisconsin CCA Board Election Results
items.description: Thank you to everyone who provided nominations and voted in the recent Wisconsin CCA Board election. On-behalf of the election process I would like to welcome Rob Shields, Matt Brugger, and Chris Bandura to the …
items.summary:
The Wisconsin CCA (Certified Crop Adviser) Board election results have been announced. Rob Shields, Matt Brugger, and Chris Bandura have been elected to the WI CCA Board and are eligible to serve two, three-year terms.

The election process was managed by the Outreach Program Manager, Daniel H. Smith, from the Crops and Soils Program at the University of Wisconsin-Madison Division of Extension.

All WI CCAs in good standing are eligible for nomination and can vote in future elections, which will be held in early 2025. Individuals who did not get elected this time are encouraged to apply again in the next election cycle.

The announcement was made on May 10, 2024 in the WCM (Wisconsin Crop Manager) newsletter and the "What's New?" section.
